FuncDef:
The ipv6 nd anti-attack rate-limit command sets the rate limit value for ND packets.
The undo ipv6 nd anti-attack rate-limit command deletes the rate limit value for ND packets.
By default, the ND anti-attack function is disabled.
CLIs: ipv6 nd { ns | na | rs | ra } anti-attack rate-limit <limit>
undo ipv6 nd { ns | na | rs | ra } anti-attack rate-limit <limit>

ParaDef.Info:
Indicates the rate at which NS messages are sent.
-

Indicates the rate at which NA messages are sent.
-

Indicates the rate at which RS messages are sent.
-

Indicates the rate at which RA messages are sent.
-

Specify the speed limit value for ND packets.
The value is an integer ranging from 0 to 5000, in pps.

ExtraInfo:
Usage Scenario
If users send a large number of ND packets to a device. Many resources are diverted into processing these ND packets, and the processing of other services is affected. To resolve this problem, run the ipv6 nd anti-attack rate-limit(interface view) command to set the rate limit value for ND packets based on interface suppression type, avoid the waste of equipment on processing ND packets to ensure the normal operation of other services.
Configuration Impact
After set the rate limit value for ND packets, the device counts the number of received ND packets. If the number of ND packets received in a specified period exceeds the upper limit, the device discards the excess ND packets. As a result, the device may fail to process some valid ND packets, causing service interruptions.
Precautions
If the rate limit is too low and the login through telnet fails because the device receives a large number of attack packets, you can log in to the device through the Console port to increase the rate limit.
